bibl.title: Proposal from Philip Showalter Hench to the Mayo Clinic Publications Committee, December 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench makes a formal request to register the preparation of a book on the history of the conquest of yellow fever. He assures the Committee on Medical Education and Research at the Mayo Clinic that this work will not interfere with his research on rheumatic diseases nor his work on experimental jaundice.

div1.head: Proposal from Philip Showalter Hench to the Mayo Clinic Publications Committee, December 11, 1941
div1.p: Recommended to the Publications Committee for approval.
Committee on Medical Education and Research

To the Committee on Medical Education and Research for your action, and also
for the consideration of the Committee on Publication of Books:

I should like to make a formal request to register the preparation
of a book on the history of the conquest of yellow fever. As you may know, I
have been working on this as a hobby for the last four years and have done much
work on it myself out of hours and on personal vacations. My secretary, Miss
Schnurr, has helped me tremendously and to date the whole thing has been rather
informal. A good deal of the correspondence has been done in regular hours
incidental to the publication of three papers thereon. A good deal has also
been done out of hours for which I have paid Miss Schnurr and Miss Nelson small
extra sums. I have collected a considerable amount of unpublished material
based on records, the unpublished accounts of eye witnesses, the lost and now
found notebooks of Lazear, etc. There are of sufficient historical importance
that they should be published. I do not propose to let the preparation of this
book interfere with my researches on rheumatic diseases and my work on experimental
jaundice. In other words, I plan to work on the yellow fever business only as a
hobby and essentially out of hours but would like to have it listed officially
for various reasons. If your committee approves the eventual publication of such
a book, would you kindly notify me or my secretary what should be done about any
further stenographic work that she does. I have personally paid for much of the
photographic work incidental to the three papers already written but the photo-
graphic department has also helped me greatly. It would be rather difficult to
separate that amount of work which I have paid for and that which Miss Schnurr
and others have done although I do have copies of everything that we have written.

I have not as yet attempted to make any arrangements with any publisher.
The book should be written to interest laymen as well as medical men. The proposed
title would probably be “The Conquest of Yellow Fever” or perhaps some more arresting
title, one more interesting to laymen. It should be a rather small book, perhaps
150 pages but with a generous number of illustrations. As to the estimate of the
demand for the book, I have no idea. I can only say that the yellow fever story
continues more and more to catch the fancy of the public, as witnessed by the
play and the movie “Yellow Jack”.

The war may interfere with any large publication of the book
and it might be well to publish it 4 or 5 years from now
But I do want authorization and advice so that I can
slowly collect the necessary data.

DoctorHench: This was approved, as you know, by the Board of
Governors at the suggestion of our Committee.
